Description: Cotes et isles vues de la flotte, one of ten studies for Plate 1 of the artist's 'Voyage dans la Basse et la Haute Egypte, pendant les campagnes du Général Bonaparte', 1802; view of the west and north coast of Cap Corse, seen from the North-West, with to the left Santa Maria Tower and to the right Saint Florent Pen and black ink, with grey wash
Producer name: Drawn by: Baron Dominique Vivant Denon
Curator's comments: Engraved by Jean Baptiste Réville. There is no copy of Denon's 'Voyage...' in the Department of Prints and Drawings; the volume of plates is both in the library of Ancient Egypt and Sudan and in the Anthropology Library. The British Library copy is at 458.h.12. The minutes of the Trustees' meeting on 12th December, 1835, record that "two or three" of the drawings were missing when the group was offered to the Museum. Literature: for an overview of Denon as a draughtsman, see Madeleine Pinault-Sørensen, '"Je fis un dessin": les dessins de Dominique Vivant Denon en Egypte', in 'Vivant Denon. Colloque de Chalon-sur-Saône' 2007, pp.49-96.
Associated names: Associated with: Napoléon I, Emperor of the French (Napoleon)
Illustration to: Baron Dominique Vivant Denon
Associated titles: Voyage dans la Basse et la Haute Egypte
Acquisition notes: The Denon Egyptian campaign drawings in the BM were lots 892 and 893 (pp. 204-205) in the posthumous Denon sale held in Paris in 1826. The lots were offered together and were unsold at 1000 francs. The BM purchased 1836,0109.1 to 206 from an unidentified 'Duncan' for £40 the group. Since the purchase is recorded in the printed 'List of additions made to the collections in the British Museum in the year 1835', p.473, the acquisition was presumably made late in the previous year although registered as the beginning of 1836.
